discussion.content:
Multi-Cloud automation and orchestration platform for Cisco and third-party servers, networks, storage, and converged infrastructure. → UCS Director

Software as a Service Platform that enables Cisco infrastructure management, automation, and orchestration from anywhere. → Cisco Intersight

Embedded software that enables Cisco server, fabric, and storage provisioning. → UCS Manager
It is correct

The correct answer is A.
Cisco IOS XE Software uses gNMI Protocol as a model-driven configuration.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/1610/b_1610_programmability_cg/gnmi_protocol.html
Answer: A

questions.question_text: Which model-driven programmability protocol does Cisco IOS XE Software support?

choices.B: bootstrap a device that has a factory-default configuration
choices.C: send CLI commands to a device and retrieve output in JSON format
choices.D: run Linux commands natively on the device
choices.A: configure a device with native and OpenConfig-based models

discussion.content:
A is correct. Anyone can create YANG data models. Nn most cases, they are
created by network equipment vendors, the IETF, and OpenConfig.
A is correct

A

It's A

questions.question_text: Which operation is performed with YANG model-driven programmability in NX-OS?

discussion.content: C & E are correct. (from "DevNet Associate Fundaments")

Selected Answer: CE
C & E are the most suitable

Selected Answer: AC
Better options than c&e

Selected Answer: AC
A and C

E. model-driven APIs for abstraction and simplification: This answer choice is not correct. While model-driven programmability can provide some abstraction and simplification when designing and implementing APIs, it is not the primary benefit of this approach. The primary benefits are easier design, deployment, and management of APIs, and decoupling of the API from transport, protocol, and encoding.

Selected Answer: CE
C and E are correct.
Model-Driven Programmability provides:

- Configuration language that is human-readable
- Model-based, structured, and computer-friendly
- Include support for multiple model types, including native, OpenConfig, and IETF
- The specification is decoupled from transport, protocol end encoding.
- Use model-driven APIs for abstraction and simplification.
- Leverage open-source and enjoy wide support
C & E - bullets are in slide 8 - https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2018/pdf/BRKSPG-2303.pdf

choices.B: single choice of transport, protocol, and encoding
choices.E: model-driven APIs for abstraction and simplification
choices.C: models decoupled from transport, protocol, and encoding
choices.A: easier to design, deploy, and manage APIs
